choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.text: A new vaccine has been developed to target the 23 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae. This polysaccharide vaccine promises to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with pneumococcal infections, particularly in certain high-risk groups. Which of the following patient groups would most likely derive the most benefit from this vaccine? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A patient with sickle cell disease 

 

  • The polysaccharide vaccine targeting Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) provides the greatest advantages to individuals with sickle cell disease.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a bacteria enveloped in a protective layer that the spleen recognizes and eliminates.
  • However, in the case of sickle cell disease, the distorted shape of red blood cells obstructs the spleen's blood vessels, leading to damage.
  • This compromised spleen function, known as hyposplenism, raises the susceptibility to pneumococcal infections.
  • Consequently, sickle cell patients receive the pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) as a preventive measure, aimed at diminishing this vulnerability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A child < 2 years: Polysaccharide vaccines are not effective in children under 2 years old due to their immature immune systems. Conjugate vaccines are preferred for this age group.

 

Option C. A patient with cystic fibrosis: While at risk for lung infections, cystic fibrosis patients benefit more from vaccines targeting typical respiratory pathogens, and their spleen function is usually normal.

 

Option D. A patient with recurrent otitis media: This condition is typically managed with other interventions, and the need for a polysaccharide vaccine is less critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The PPSV-23 vaccine is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease due to their increased susceptibility to pneumococcal infections caused by compromised spleen function.

questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You're rotating in the infection control unit of a tertiary care hospital in Chennai. As part of your duties, you have been assigned to educate the staff about the importance of precautionary measures and isolation techniques for various conditions. While discussing droplet precautions, one of the staff inquired about the diseases for which such precautions are necessary. Which of the following conditions does NOT typically require precautionary measures and isolation due to droplet infection? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Localized varicella zoster

 

  • Droplet precautions and isolation are unnecessary for localized varicella-zoster, as this virus is exclusively transmitted through direct contact.
  • When varicella-zoster remains confined to a patient with a fully functioning immune system and can be effectively contained or covered, there is no need for droplet precautions.
  • However, if varicella becomes disseminated in any patient, it necessitates both airborne and contact precautions.
  • On the other hand, diseases like diphtheria, pertussis, and mycoplasma are transmitted via droplets and, therefore, demand droplet precautions and isolation measures.
  • These precautions include the use of masks, gowns, gloves, and protective eye gear when delivering direct patient care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pertussis: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Requires droplet precautions as it is spread through respiratory droplets.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumonia: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation in infectious diseases, a patient with dengue fever develops warning signs like abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, clinical fluid accumulation, and an increase in hematocrit with a decrease in platelet count. Which of the following is the cornerstone of management for a patient showing warning signs of dengue? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) IV Fluids 

 

  • The mainstay treatment for patients with dengue showing warning signs is intravenous (IV) fluid therapy.
  • This approach is crucial to prevent progression to severe dengue, including dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: Only indicated if there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm³) with active bleeding.

 

Option C. Cryoglobulins: Not relevant for dengue management.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): Not a primary treatment for dengue with warning signs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company has developed a novel diagnostic test for a rare metabolic disorder. In clinical trials, the test demonstrated a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.80. In a population where the prevalence of the disease is 30%, the test was applied to every participant. What is the probability that a person who tests negative truly does not have the disease? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 95%

 

  • It’s the Negative Predictive Value (NPV), which tells us the probability that a person with a negative test result truly doesn't have the disease.

 NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

  • Use a hypothetical cohort of 1000 people for easy calculation.

 

Given:

 

  • Disease prevalence = 30% = 300 people with the disease and 700 without the disease out of 1000.
  • Sensitivity = 0.90, so TP = 0.90 * 300 = 270 and FN = 300 - 270 = 30.
  • Specificity = 0.80, so TN = 0.80 * 700 = 560 and FP = 700 - 560 = 140.

 

Using the above formula:

 

NPV = 560 / (560 + 30) = 560 / 590 = 0.9491 or approximately 95%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Negative Predictive Value (NPV) represents the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease

choices.text: 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

questions.text: Dr. Sanjana is leading a health initiative in Karnataka, focusing on the prevention of anemia among adult women through the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative. She needs to communicate the correct dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation. What is the recommended dose according to the guidelines? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

 

  • As per the Anemia Mukth Bharat initiative guidelines, it is recommended for adult females to consume 60 mg of elemental iron along with 500 mcg of folic acid in tablet form on a weekly basis.
  • These tablets have a sugar-coated exterior and are colored red.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A new combined treatment regimen of chemotherapy and immunotherapy has significantly increased survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. If the number of new cases remains consistent, but patients live longer, which epidemiological impact would be observed? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • Due to the new drug combination, patient survival rates have risen, resulting in a situation where the incidence remains unchanged while prevalence sees an increase.

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Since New cases will keep on occurring at the same rate, Incidence will remain same. Duration will increase (as survival increases). So, overall Prevalence will increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When patient survival increases due to a new treatment, the incidence of the disease remains the same, but the prevalence increases due to longer survival duration.

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus

 

NIPAH Virus

 

  • Genus: Henapi virus
  • Transmission in India:
    • Occurrence: West Bengal, Kerela (Kozhikode district)
    • Route: Consumption of fruits contaminated with bats (Pteropus: ‘Flying foxes’) secretions (person - person in India) 
    • Direct contact with infected bats, infected pigs, infected people
  • Clinical presentation: Encephalitis
  • IP is 4-14 days
  • Case fatality rate: 50%
  • Vaccine: NONE for humans
  • Treatment: Intensive supportive care
    • High-risk contacts and healthcare workers, who are under quarantine and monitoring for 21 days
  • WHO included Nipah virus under list of Emerging Diseases likely to cause Major Epidemics 
  • Comes under Category C of Bioterrorism agent 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Japanese encephalitis: Transmitted by mosquitoes and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Option B. Zika virus: Transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes species, and does not match the transmission cycle shown in the image.

 

ZIKA VIRUS LIFE CYCLE

 

 

 

Option C. Rabies: Transmitted through the bites of infected animals (typically dogs or other mammals) and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

questions.text: Dr. Verma is examining the criteria used to establish the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) for nutrients and focuses on the typical characteristics of a "reference woman". Which of the following correctly describes this reference woman used for RDA calculations? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Weight 55 kgs

 

  • Weight of 55 kgs: This is used as a standard measurement in RDA calculations to reflect an average baseline for determining nutrient needs in adult women.
  • It represents a balance that is thought to be typical or ideal for maintaining health without excessive caloric intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference woman used in the calculation of recommended daily allowance (RDA)

 

  • Aged between 19-39 years
  • Non pregnant, non-lactating
  • Weight=55kgs
  • Height = 1.61 m
  • BMI=21.2
  • Free from disease and physically fit for active work
  • Engaged in moderate activity for 8 hours on each working day
  • Spends 8 hours in bed, 4-6 hours in sitting and moving, 2hours in walking and in active recreation or household activities.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible
Clear eyes with a sterile swab
Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Bath to newborn with warm water

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended as it can cause rapid heat loss and hypothermia in the infant. Instead, after delivery, the newborn should be wiped clean with a sterile cloth and wrapped warmly without giving a bath. The bath can be delayed until at least 24 hours after birth or later when the baby’s body temperature has stabilized, especially in settings without advanced care facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start breastfeeding as soon as possible: It is recommended to initiate breastfeeding immediately after birth, ideally within the first hour for vaginal deliveries and within 4 hours for cesarean sections. Early breastfeeding provides the newborn with essential nutrients and antibodies and helps stimulate milk production.

 

Option B. Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the eyes of a newborn with a sterile swab is correct. If needed, antiseptic solutions like 1% silver nitrate or 1% tetracycline ointment can be used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum, an eye infection that can occur in newborns.

 

Option D. Cover baby’s head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is essential to prevent heat loss. Newborns lose up to 75% of their body heat through the head, making it crucial to keep the baby warm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: A child presented to PHC OPD with skin rash and depigmented hair. He gives a history of swollen/bleeding gums. X-ray picture is shown below. He is suffering from: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Copper deficiency


The clinical presentation of the child, including skin rash, depigmented hair, swollen/bleeding gums, and the X-ray findings, suggests a deficiency that closely mimics scurvy (vitamin C deficiency). However, in this question, the exact cause is copper deficiency, which shares similar symptoms and radiological appearances with scurvy. Copper plays a crucial role in various metabolic pathways, including those influenced by vitamin C, such as collagen synthesis and connective tissue health. Copper deficiency is known as pseudoscurvy because it presents with nearly identical clinical and radiological features as vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zinc deficiency: Zinc deficiency typically presents with symptoms such as delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, and dermatitis, particularly around orifices. It does not cause the specific combination of bleeding gums, depigmented hair, and the radiological changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency usually presents with symptoms related to anemia, such as fatigue, pallor, and pica. While it can cause brittle nails and hair changes, it does not present with bleeding gums and specific X-ray findings as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency: Selenium deficiency primarily affects the heart and muscles, leading to conditions like Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and muscle weakness. It does not cause the bleeding gums, depigmented hair, or the bone abnormalities observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Copper deficiency can mimic vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) in its clinical and radiological presentation, a condition often referred to as pseudoscurvy.

questions.text: Which of the following elements is not included in the provisions of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017, as per the WHO's mhGAP? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening of family members

 

  • The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 focuses on the rights and treatment of patients with mental illness, but it does not specifically include provisions for the screening of family members.
  • The Act covers various aspects such as the capacity to make healthcare decisions, advance directives, nominated representatives, types of admissions, bans on certain treatments (like direct ECT for minors and psychosurgery), decriminalization of suicide attempts, and regulations on restraints and seclusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mobilization of resources: The Act includes provisions related to the mobilization of resources for mental health services.

 

Option C. Social support: Social support is a crucial aspect of mental health care covered under the Act, ensuring that patients receive necessary support from family and community.

 

Option D. Interpersonal therapy: While specific therapies may not be explicitly listed, the Act does promote access to various mental health treatments, which can include interpersonal therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening of family members is not included in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017.

 

Additional Information

 

MENTAL HEALTHCARE ACT, 2017 (MHCA 2017)

 

  • Deals with rights of patients with mental illness and treatment delivery. Important clauses-

 

A. Capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision- Every person, including patients with mental illness, are assumed to have it if they can-

 

  • Can understand the information provided to them
  • Understand the consequences of their decisions
  • Can communicate their decision

 

B. Advance directive- Every person (not a minor) can make an advance directive in which he can mention-

 

  • How they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness
  • Applicable only if a person loses the capacity to take mental healthcare or treatment decisions
  • Duty of psychiatrist (or medical officer) to give treatment according to the advance directive
  • Doctor is not liable in case of unforeseen consequences while following the advance directive

 

C. Nominated representative (NR)-

 

  • Every person can appoint a nominated representative
  • In case of loss of capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision, NR would help in taking decisions about treatment

 

D. Admission- MHCA 2017 allows two types of admissions

 

  • Independent admissions- When the patient himself wants to get admitted
  • Supported admission (for a maximum of 30 days)- A person who has lost the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions and requires significant support from a nominated representative can be admitted under a “supported admission”

 

E. Ban on direct ECT

 

F. Ban on ECT for minors

 

G. Ban on psychosurgery

 

H. Decriminalisation of suicide attempt - Any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished

 

I. Restraints and seclusions - A patient can be physically restrained only-

 

  • If it is the only way to prevent harm to self or others
  • If authorised by a psychiatrist in charge

choices.text: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.text: A sensitive diagnostic test for a certain disease returns a positive result for a patient. What statement accurately describes the significance of a positive result from the sensitive test? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common

 

  • If a sensitive test yields a positive result, it indicates the presence of the disease, especially when the disease is prevalent.
  • The sensitivity of a screening test refers to its capacity to accurately identify individuals with the disease.
  • In simpler terms, sensitivity measures the test's capability to correctly spot true positives (TP) among all cases of the disease (TP+FN). 

 

Sensitivity = TP / TP + FN X 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It confirms that the person does not have the disease: Incorrect. A sensitive test returning a positive result indicates the presence, not the absence, of the disease.

 

Option B. It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease: Incorrect. If the disease is rare, the positive predictive value (PPV) might be low, and the result may be less reliable.

 

Option D. It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent: Incorrect. While a positive result is more likely in a prevalent disease, it does not solely rely on sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive result from a highly sensitive test confirms the presence of the disease, particularly when the disease is common.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) STD clinic attendees

 

  • Routine monitoring for HIV is generally not conducted among individuals visiting STD clinics.
  • Sentinel surveillance serves to enhance the existing notification systems employed for disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single male migrants: Included in sentinel surveillance as they are considered at high risk.

 

Option B. Truck drivers: Included due to their high-risk behavior.

 

Option D. Antenatal women: Included to monitor HIV prevalence among pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sites for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

 

  • A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • Female sex workers.
  • Hijra/Transgenders.
  • IV drug users
  • Truckers.
  • Homosexual Men
  • Migrants.

choices.text: Washing hands with soap and water
Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.text: During a busy day at the outpatient clinic, a nurse accidentally sustains a needle stick injury while drawing blood from a patient known to have HIV. She asks for guidance on immediate management steps to mitigate her risk of acquiring the infection. Which of the following recommendations would NOT be appropriate? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Administration of tenofovir monotherapy

 

  • Triple drug PEP regimens are now the recommended regimens for all exposures owing to the safety and tolerability of new HIV drugs. Tenofovir 300mg + Lamivudine 300mg + Dolutegravir 50mg is recommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), not monotherapy.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV consists of a comprehensive set of services to prevent infection developing in an exposed person, including first aid care; counselling and risk assessment; HIV testing and counselling; and, depending on the risk assessment, the short term (28 days) provision of antiretroviral drugs, with support and follow-up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Washing hands with soap and water: This is an appropriate initial step.

 

Option C. Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately: This is necessary to establish the baseline and monitor for any seroconversion.

 

Option D. Measure viral markers after 6 weeks: Follow-up testing is crucial to detect any potential infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For needle stick injuries involving HIV exposure, a triple drug regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis is recommended, not monotherapy.
  • Immediate washing, baseline viral markers, and follow-up testing are also critical components of the management protocol.

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

choices.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group
Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.text: Dr. Aishwarya, a public health official, is discussing the maternal health situation in a rural district of Uttar Pradesh at a Panchayat meeting. She emphasizes the importance of understanding the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for her district. Which definition best describes the MMR? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births 

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality rate (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.
  • MMR is a ratio (Maternal mortality rate is a misnomer; MMR is not a rate)

 

 

Additional Information

 

  • MMR World: 216 per 100,000 live births; Causes of MMR (globally):
    • Hemorrhage (25%)
    • Indirect causes (20%)
    • Infection (15%)
    • Unsafe abortion (13%)
    • Eclampsia (12%)
    • Obstructed labour (8%)
  • MMR India: 97 per 100,000 live births [2023]; Causes of MMR (India) [SRS 2023]:
    • Hemorrhage (38%)
    • Other conditions (34%)
    • Sepsis (11%)
    • Abortion (8%)
    • Obstructed labour (5%)
    • Hypertensive disorders (5%)
  • Maternal mortality rate (MMRate): Dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. 

 

MMRate reflects not only the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth, but also the level of fertility in a population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MMR is a crucial indicator of maternal health in a population, reflecting the risk of maternal death associated with childbirth and its management.
  • It is typically expressed per 100,000 live births to provide a clear picture of maternal health risks and the effectiveness of health interventions aimed at reducing these risks in specific areas or populations.

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the primary concern addressed by the POCSO Act? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Child sexual abuse

 

  • The POCSO Act (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012 is designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse and exploitation.
  • It includes provisions for punishment of various offenses such as penetrative sexual assault, aggravated penetrative sexual assault, sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, sexual harassment, and the use of children for pornography.
  • The act ensures stringent punishment for offenders to provide a safe and secure environment for children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Women empowerment: Incorrect. The POCSO Act is focused on protecting children from sexual offenses, not specifically on women empowerment.

 

Option B. Human trafficking: Incorrect. While important, human trafficking is not the primary focus of the POCSO Act.

 

Option C. Juvenile delinquency: Incorrect. The act deals with protecting children from sexual offenses, not addressing juvenile delinquency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POCSO Act (Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012

 

  • Child definition: Any person less than 18 years of age
  • Includes: Sexual abuses and pornography
  • Punishments under the act:

questions.text: Dr. Sharma, the head of the pediatric department at a renowned medical college in Uttar Pradesh, is conducting a training session for new medical officers. As part of the session, he aims to ensure the officers are well-versed with the national health programs related to child health. He poses the question, "Under the Rashtriya Bal Swashthya Karyakram (RBSK) initiative, which of these diseases is not covered? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Congenital glaucoma

 

  • While congenital cataract is explicitly mentioned as part of the initiative's coverage, congenital glaucoma is not typically listed among the prioritized conditions for screening under the RBSK.
  • This omission might be due to the relative rarity or specific screening requirements of congenital glaucoma compared to more commonly addressed conditions in public health programs.

 

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

 

  • Importance: Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Services Program under National Rural Health Mission
  • Target group:
    • 0-6 years old children (Rural areas + Urban slums)
    • 6-18 years old children (Enrolled in government schools)
  • Targeted diseases (4D’s):
    • Defects at birth
    • Diseases in children
    • Deficiency conditions
    • Developmental delays including disabilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Targeted diseases:

questions.text: A 38-year-old man from a rural area of Bihar presents to the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital in Patna. He has been experiencing fever for the past week, associated with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and palpable lymphadenopathy. Despite being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antimalarial agents by a local practitioner, there's been no significant relief. Blood investigations for typhoid (Widal test) are negative; however, the rk39 dipstick test is positive. Based on the clinical picture and the diagnostic findings, what would be the most appropriate drug of choice for the treatment of his condition? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Liposomal Amphotericin B

 

  • This clinical presentation strongly indicates the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The recommended course of action for this patient involves the administration of liposomal amphotericin B.

 

 

Incubation Period: 10 days to 2 years (average 1 – 4 months)

 

Serological tests:

 

  • ELISA: for diagnosis as well as epidemiological field survey
  • rk 39 dipstick test
  • Indirect Flourescent Antibody Test (IFAT)
  • Direct Agglutination Test

 

 Treatment of Leishmaniasis

 

  • Sodium stibogluconate
  • Miltefosine
  • Paramomycin
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (DOC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Fluconazole is an anti-fungal, not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

 

Option C: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA

 

Option D: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) should be treated with liposomal amphotericin B, especially when diagnosed with a positive rk39 dipstick test.

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 225

 

 

In the given question, out of total 456 births, 56 were dead born. 

 

Therefore, the number of live births= 456-56 = 400.

 

In the same year, it is given that the number of deaths before 28 days is 56, and the number of deaths after 28 days but before 1 year is 34.

 

Hence, the total number of deaths of children < 1 year is 56 + 34 = 90

 

IMR = (90x1000)/400 = 900/4 = 225

 

Hence, the IMR is 225 per 1000 live births.

 

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

 

  • It is the number of deaths per 1000 live births of children under one year of age. It is the most sensitive indicator of availability and utilization of health care services in a country. Is most important indicator of health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of MCH services in general. 
  • IMR is among ‘the best predictors of state failure’
  • It is a rate.
  • IMR of India (2023): 26.6 per 1000 live births; 
  • IMR of India - 35 per 1000 live births (NFHS-5 2019-21,); 28 per 1000 Live births (SRS, May 2022)
  • Is the second best indicator of socio-economic development of a country: Ultimate solution for lowering IMR lies in socio-economic development [Best indicator is U5MR]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.

 

NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)

questions.text: A resident in neurology is assessing a patient who recently sustained a traumatic brain injury using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). How should the resident describe the type of data obtained from the GCS? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal scale data

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale represents ordinal data since the GCS score is categorized as mild, moderate, or severe, following a specific order of severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal scale data: Data based on names without a specific order.

 

Option C. Alphanumerical data: Data that includes both letters and numbers, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Interval scale data: Data measured along a scale where each point is equidistant from the next, but GCS does not meet this criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.text: A newly established hospital aims to maintain the highest standards of care and ensure patient safety by standardizing injection practices among health workers. They seek a reliable method for real-time assessment of these practices. Which of the following would be the most appropriate method to monitor the injection practices of health workers? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Direct observation with a structured checklist

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.
  • This method allows for real-time, accurate assessment of adherence to aseptic techniques and best practices.
  • A structured checklist ensures all critical steps are monitored and recorded systematically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Closed circuit camera surveillance: While it may offer some insights, it lacks the detail and real-time assessment provided by direct observation.

 

Option C. In-depth interview with the patient: Patients may not have the expertise to accurately comment on the technical aspects of injection practices.

 

Option D. In-depth interview with the healthcare provider: This relies on self-reporting, which may be biased and not always accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.

questions.text: During your residency, you learn about a specific protocol essential for physicians when dealing with challenging scenarios. This protocol, known as the SPIKES protocol, serves a unique purpose in medical communication. Can you identify the primary objective of employing the SPIKES protocol? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breaking bad news

 

SPIKES PROTOCOL

 

  • Communication of cancer Diagnosis & Prognosis (or any adverse outcome)
  • Protocol of 6 steps

S - Set up interview

P - Perceptions

I - Invitation to explain

K - Knowledge

E - Emotions

S - Summary & Strategy

 

Best used for Communication of diagnosis and prognosis for Breast Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triage: Incorrect. Triage involves prioritizing patient care based on the severity of their condition.

 

Option B. Consent for study participation: Incorrect. Obtaining consent for study participation requires a different communication protocol focused on informed consent.

 

Option C. Hospital infection control: Incorrect. Infection control involves protocols for preventing and managing infections within the hospital setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SPIKES protocol is specifically designed to guide physicians in breaking bad news to patients, ensuring the communication is handled with sensitivity and clarity.

choices.text: FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.text: You work as a medical officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC). You are tasked with developing a strategy to address widespread anemia in the community. Considering the need for efficacy, safety, and ease of administration, which of the following options would you recommend for the prevention and treatment of anemia in this setting? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

 

  • Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 is likely to be the best mass prophylaxis against anemia.
  • Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance.
  • Supplementing vitamin B12 can reduce incidence and prevalence of megaloblastic anemia as cost factor is not that significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose: It is not yet evident to be more efficacious than FeSO4

 

Option C. Ferrous fumarate: It is considered to be equally efficacious but vitamin C as an adjunct improves absorption.

 

Option D. Injection iron sucrose: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is a first-line option. It is only indicated if the oral form is not tolerated or patient is not compliant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).

choices.text: Mean = median, not equal to mode
Mode = median, not equal to mean

questions.text: The image shows two data distribution curves from separate studies within the same population: one depicted with a red line and the other with a blue line. Given the graphical representation, which of the following correctly represents the relationship among the mean, median, and mode for the data presented? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mean = median, not equal to mode

 

Analyzing the two graphs, we observe different distribution patterns:

 

  • Red line (Study A): The distribution is unimodal and symmetrical, indicating that the mean, median, and mode are all equal.
  • Blue line (Study B): The distribution is bimodal, showing two distinct peaks. In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median are typically equal, but there are two modes, making the mode not equal to the mean or median.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median can be equal, but the mode will not be equal to them, as there are two modes.

choices.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of a p-value with regard to the probability related to the null hypothesis? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

 

  • The p-value represents the likelihood of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis. It serves as the threshold for determining statistical significance.
  • In essence, the p-value signifies the probability of erroneously rejecting a valid null hypothesis, leading to a Type I error.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is true, and the researcher correctly decides not to reject it. This scenario does not involve a p-value interpretation.

 

Option C. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a Type II error, where the null hypothesis is false, but the researcher fails to reject it. The p-value is not directly related to this scenario.

 

Option D. Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is false, and the researcher correctly rejects it. This is the goal of hypothesis testing but not the specific interpretation of a p-value.

 

Null Hypothesis

 

  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the Demographic cycle in the correct chronological sequence: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Low stationary
  2. High stationary
  3. Declining
  4. Early expanding
  5. Late expanding
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2 4 5 1 3

 

The Demographic Transition Model describes the stages a country goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. The stages of the demographic cycle in correct chronological order are:

 

2. High Stationary : This is the first stage characterized by high birth and high death rates, leading to a stable population. It reflects pre-industrial societies with limited medical care and poor living conditions.

 

4. Early Expanding: In this stage, death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

 

5. Late Expanding : Birth rates begin to fall as societies become more urbanized and access to contraception improves, but the population continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate.

 

1. Low Stationary : Both birth and death rates are low, stabilizing the population size. This stage reflects advanced economies with high living standards and access to family planning.

 

3. Declining : In the final stage, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a declining population. This stage is seen in highly developed countries with aging populations and very low fertility rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the demographic cycle stages is: High Stationary, Early Expanding, Late Expanding, Low Stationary, and Declining.

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Friedman test

 

  • Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used for detecting differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
  • It is the equivalent of a one-way ANOVA with repeated measures but for non-parametric data.
  • Since the data in this scenario is not normally distributed, and the groups are related, the Friedman test is the appropriate choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t-test: Student t-test is used for comparing the means of two groups. However, it assumes that the data is normally distributed. 

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of three or more independent groups. 

 

Option D. Pearson: Pearson correlation is used for measuring the strength of a linear association between two quantitative variables. It is not a test for comparing means and also assumes a normal distribution of the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

choices.text: EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence.
EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice.
EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence.
EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research.

questions.text: A recent medical graduate is attending a seminar on Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM). The speaker emphasizes EBM's integrative approach to patient care. Which statement most accurately encapsulates the core philosophy of EBM? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence

 

  • It integrates individual clinical expertise with the best external clinical evidence.
  • EBM is a combination of research evidence, clinical experience, and patient values/preferences.

 

 

  • Critical appraisal of research findings and decisions regarding whether, and how, to use findings in the care of patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence: Incorrect. EBM values a combination of different types of evidence, including clinical expertise and patient preferences.

 

Option B. EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice: Incorrect. EBM values clinical experience alongside empirical research findings.

 

Option D. EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research: Incorrect. EBM focuses on unbiased, high-quality evidence rather than recommendations from potentially biased sources.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The core philosophy of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) is to integrate the clinician's expertise with the best available external evidence and patient values to make informed clinical decisions.

questions.text: The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical parameter used to evaluate maternal health within countries. In the context of public health statistics, how is the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) for a country conventionally expressed? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.

 

MMR is a ratio 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, providing a measure of the safety and quality of maternal care in a country.

questions.text: What concentration of tetanus antitoxin in the blood is considered clinically protective against tetanus? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) >0.01 IU/ml

 

  • Specific antibody concentrations greater than 0.01 IU/mL were considered protective against tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aim of active Immunisation with TT:

 

  • Vaccinate the entire community
  • Ensure protective level of antitoxin ~ 0.01 IU/mL serum throughout life

questions.text:
Dr. Geeta, a senior epidemiologist in Delhi, receives weekly updates on the prevalence of several diseases in the states/region she oversees. Recently, she noticed distinct patterns in three different diseases over a two-week period: [AIIMS NOV 2017]

 

Disease 1: Number of cases last week = 42, this week = 43

 

Disease 2: Number of cases last week 2 and present week 42

 

Disease 3: Number of cases last week 6 and present week 1

 

How should these diseases be categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Endemic, epidemic, sporadic

 

Disease 1 - The similarity of the cases suggests that it must be endemic.

 

Disease 2 - The surge in case numbers is deeply concerning, suggesting the potential emergence of an epidemic.

 

Disease 3 - The decrease in the number of cases has occurred without a clear explanation, suggesting that it may be sporadic in nature. An epidemic, on the other hand, is characterized by the occurrence of a disease at a rate exceeding the expected frequency.

 

Endemic

 

  • Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
  • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
  • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Pandemic

 

  • An epidemic usually affecting a large proportion of the population, occurring over a large geographical area such as part of a nation, nation, continent or world (Country-to-country spread)

 

Sporadic

 

  • Cases which are ‘scattered about’
    • Cases are widely separated in space and time
    • Show little or no connection with each other
    • There is no recognizable source of infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic diseases show a stable presence, epidemics show a sudden increase in cases, and sporadic diseases occur irregularly.

questions.text: A cotton swab, pus stained, is disposed in which color of BMW management category? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow category

 

  • According to the latest BMW (Biomedical Waste Management) guidelines 2017-2018, biomedical waste is categorized into four main categories based on the type of waste and its disposal method. 
  • The yellow category includes human anatomical waste, animal waste, soiled waste (which includes cotton, gauge pieces, bandages, dressings), discarded medicines, and chemical waste.
  • Cotton swabs that are stained with pus are classified as soiled waste and therefore should be disposed of in the yellow category. 
  • The yellow category waste is typically disposed of through incineration (at 1200°C) or plasma pyrolysis. 
  • In some specific cases, especially at the PHC level, deep burial may also be used for certain types of yellow category waste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red category: Incorrect. The red category is meant for solid/contaminated (recyclable) waste including plastic and rubber items such as tubings, catheters, and cannulas. 

 

 

Option C. White category: Incorrect. The white category is specifically designated for waste sharps such as needles, surgical blades, and scalpels.

 

 

Option D. Blue category: Incorrect. The blue category is for glassware, orthopedic metallic body implants, and other items from ENT, dental, cardio-thoracic, and vascular surgery. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cotton swabs stained with pus are classified as soiled waste and should be disposed of in the yellow category of biomedical waste management.

questions.text: A diagram illustrating the natural history of a disease has points marked A, B, C, and D. Which point indicates the onset of symptoms in the disease's natural history? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Point C

 

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

 

Option B. Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Up to 48 hours

 

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) insertion timing can be categorized into three main periods:

 

  1. During Menstruation: IUCD insertion during menstruation is preferred within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to ensure the woman is not pregnant and to ease insertion due to the open cervical os.
  2. Immediate Postpartum: The best time for postpartum IUCD insertion is within the first 48 hours after delivery. If not done within this window, insertion can be performed up to 1 week postpartum. This timing is optimal as the cervix is dilated, and there is a reduced risk of expulsion compared to later periods.
  3. Post Puerperal: If IUCD insertion is not performed immediately postpartum, the next preferred timing is 6 to 8 weeks after delivery when the uterus has involuted and stabilized.

 

For this question, since the woman has just delivered, the most precise and preferred time is within the first 48 hours postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

choices.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles - 1, Vit. A -1

questions.text: A pediatrician in a remote village encounters an 18-month-old child with no vaccination history. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which set of vaccines should the child receive? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles -1, Vit. A - 1

 

  • According to India's National Immunization Schedule (NIS), an 18-month-old child who has not received any immunizations should be given their initial doses of DPT, OPV, measles vaccine, and vitamin A.

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case studies

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.text: To accurately calculate the perinatal mortality rate, which of the following should specifically be considered as part of the numerator? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g 

 

Perinatal Mortality Rate (PNMR)

 

  • It includes both late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.

 

 

  • Perinatal period is from 28 weeks period of gestation to 7th completed days of life (But the WHO definition of perinatal period is from 22 completed weeks gestation to 7th completed days of life).
  • PNMR is a major marker to assess the quality of health care delivery; PNMR is a” Yardstick of Obstetric and Pediatric care before and around the time of birth”
  • P List (ICD 10): 100 causes of perinatal mortality and morbidity
  • PNMR of India (2022) - 18 per 1000 LB (SRS, September 2022)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perinatal mortality rate includes late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths, focusing on the period from 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has a greyish white membrane over tonsils and presented with bull-neck appearance. She has a 2-year-old brother who is fully immunized for his age. What should be given to the brother? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Nothing should be given

 

The 5-year-old girl shows clinical signs of diphtheria, characterized by a greyish white membrane over the tonsils and bull-neck appearance. The question asks about the appropriate management for her fully immunized 2-year-old brother, who is a close contact.

 

 

For contacts of a diphtheria case:

 

  • If the contact (in this case, the brother) has received primary immunization or a booster within the last 2 years, no additional intervention is needed.
  • If the immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, then a booster dose is required to maintain protection.
  • If the contact is completely unimmunized – Prophylactic t/t with Penicillin or Erythromycin along with 1000-2000 units Diphtheria antitoxin, and start immunization of contact

 

Medical surveillance needs to be done daily and

 

Bacteriological surveillance – swabs on weekly basis 

 

Since the brother is fully immunized for his age, and presumably within the past 2 years, no additional treatment is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillin:  This is used as prophylactic treatment for contacts who are completely unimmunized. It is not indicated for those who are fully vaccinated.

 

Option C.  Diphtheria antitoxin: This is administered to unimmunized contacts for immediate passive immunity, especially when there is a high risk of exposure, but it is not required for fully immunized individuals.

 

Option D.  1 dose of DPT booster:  This is given if the last dose of primary immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, but not needed if within the last 2 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In managing contacts of diphtheria, no additional doses are required if the contact has received primary immunization or booster within the last 2 years.

questions.text: During a telemedicine session with patients in a rural health clinic, Dr. Reddy emphasized preventive measures for COVID-19. He highlighted certain practices that are widely recommended. Which of the following, however, is NOT effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1% glutaraldehyde

 

  • A 1% glutaraldehyde solution does not prove effective in preventing the transmission of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face Mask: Wearing face masks significantly helps reduce the transmission of COVID-19 by blocking respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. 70% Alcohol: Alcoholic solutions, particularly those containing at least 60-70% alcohol, are effective in killing viruses on surfaces and are recommended for hand sanitation to reduce viral transmission.

 

Option D. Hand Washing: Regular and thorough hand washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is one of the most effective ways to remove viruses and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key measures that effectively curb its spread include behaviors such as maintaining a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others, washing hands with soap and water for a duration of 20 seconds, or employing a hand sanitizer containing a minimum of 70% alcohol.
  • Additionally, wearing a face mask in situations necessitating public outings remains crucial.

questions.text: Two distinct patient cohorts at AIIMS New Delhi are subjected to different treatments to monitor their post-treatment blood pressure levels. The groups do not have overlapping members. Which statistical test would best suit the analysis of the blood pressure differences between the two groups? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unpaired t test

 

  • In the provided situation, two distinct groups are under comparison, and therefore, the appropriate statistical analysis would involve employing a Student's t-test or an unpaired t-test.
  • T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired t test: Used when comparing the same group before and after an intervention, not suitable for independent groups.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means among three or more groups.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: Used for categorical data, not for comparing means of continuous data.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A particular community population has been consuming Maize as a staple diet for years. The vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this population is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Niacin

 

Maize, commonly consumed as a staple food in many communities, is deficient in the amino acid tryptophan, which is crucial for the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3) in the body. Niacin can be synthesized endogenously from tryptophan at a conversion rate of 60 mg of tryptophan to 1 mg of niacin. However, when maize is a primary dietary component, the body lacks sufficient tryptophan, leading to niacin deficiency.

 

Moreover, maize is high in leucine, an amino acid that inhibits the conversion of tryptophan to niacin via the kynurenine pathway. This combination of low tryptophan and high leucine content makes niacin deficiency prevalent in populations consuming maize as a staple diet, resulting in pellagra.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the “4 Ds”: Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and Death if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency is typically associated with polished rice consumption, not maize. It leads to conditions like beriberi.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, though possible, is not specifically linked to maize consumption. It typically results from general dietary insufficiency of various foods, not specific to maize.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin: Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency is generally seen in populations with low intake of animal products and is not related to maize consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maize as a staple diet leads to niacin deficiency due to its low tryptophan and high leucine content, resulting in pellagra.

 

Note – Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic liver disease is evaluated using the Child-Pugh score, which categorizes patients into classes based on disease severity. Which type of data does the Child-Pugh scoring system represent? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity and prognosis of chronic liver disease by categorizing patients into different classes based on specific criteria.
  • This score assigns patients to Class A, B, or C based on their total points, indicating varying levels of disease severity and prognosis.
  • It is an ordinal scale of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal: Incorrect. Nominal data involves categories without order, which does not apply to the ordered nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Option C. Qualitative: Incorrect. While the Child-Pugh score is qualitative in describing severity, the specific classification into ordered categories makes it ordinal.

 

Option D. Metric: Incorrect. Metric data involves quantitative measurements with consistent intervals, which does not describe the ordinal nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During your rural internship, you are tasked with overseeing vaccine distribution to Community Health Centres (CHCs) and Primary Health Centres (PHCs). Due to the tropical climate and frequent power outages at your posting area, ensuring the vaccines' integrity is crucial. Which of the following tests would you employ to check if the vaccines have incurred any freeze damage due to temperature fluctuations? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shake test

 

  • Utility: Used to check if Freeze sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to freezing temperatures below 0 degrees C; After the test the previously Frozen vaccine shows flakes. Shake Test is used to assess the freeze damage to Aluminium based freeze sensitive vaccines such as DPT, TT, Td etc. 
  • Method of Shake test:
    • Test Vial: Vial which is suspected to have been frozen 
    • Frozen control vial: Take a similar (as Test vial) vaccine vial with same manufacturer, batch number, antigen(s), Label it properly. Freeze it overnight at -20 degrees C, then let it haw (Do not heat)
    • Hold the Test vial and Control vials between thumb and forefinger and shake them vigorously (10-15 seconds)
    • Place both vials on even flat surface for 30 minutes observation, compare the sedimentation rates (SR). If the sediments in the suspect vial settle more slowly, the suspect vaccine may be used.
  • Interpretation:
    • If SR in Test vial < Control vial: Vaccine had not been damaged
    • If SR in Test vial > Control vial: Vaccine had been damaged,

 

Do not use and Inform the supervisors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schick test: This is a skin test for susceptibility to diphtheria.

 

Option C. Habel test: This is used to measure the potency of rabies vaccines.

 

Option D. Tine test: This is a skin test for tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Shake Test currently applies to freeze sensitive vaccines which are:

 

  • DPT-Hep B-Hib
  • TT
  • PCV13
  • Hepatitis B
  • HPV

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) VVM

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with 2-3 hypopigmented, slightly raised patches on his forearm with reduced sensation for 4 months. He is diagnosed with paucibacillary leprosy. What is the recommended treatment regimen? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 2 drug therapy for 6 months

 

  • The treatment regimen for paucibacillary leprosy involves a 6-month course of drug therapy with 2 drugs (Dapsone, Rifampicin).
  • Diagnosis of leprosy under NLEP: It is currently based on clinical grounds (revised case definition) - 

 

Paucibacillary (PB) case: A case of leprosy with 1 to 5 skin lesions, without demonstrated presence of bacilli in a skin smear;

 

Multibacillary (MB) case: A case of leprosy with more than five skin lesions; or with nerve involvement (pure neuritis, or any number of skin lesions and neuritis); or with the demonstrated presence of bacilli in a slit-skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

MDT blister pack Colour

MBL adult - Red color

 

PBL child - Blue color

 

MBL child - Yellow colour

  • Life cycle of Trombiculid mite with transovarial transmission

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is an Arbovirus transmitted by Sand fly (Phlebotomus)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes, recently diagnosed with end-stage renal disease (stage 5) and on hemodialysis, seeks dietary advice. Which of the following characterizes the ideal renal feed for him? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Low volume, high calories

 

  • An ideal diet for a patient with end-stage renal disease should consist of low volume but high calorie intake. The patient's dietary choices can significantly impact the advancement of kidney disease and its associated complications. Opting for a diet that is low in volume is recommended to prevent:
    • Sodium and volume overload
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation
  • Opting for a high-calorie diet is recommended for the potential malnutrition and wasting risks observed in individuals with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High volume, low calories: This could lead to volume overload and insufficient caloric intake.

 

Option C. High volume, high calories: High volume can cause fluid overload issues.

 

Option D. Low volume, low calories: Insufficient calories can exacerbate malnutrition and wasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An ideal diet for patients with end-stage renal disease should be low in volume to manage fluid balance and high in calories to prevent malnutrition and wasting.

questions.text: A 28-year-old public health nurse is attending a seminar on primary prevention strategies. She needs to identify interventions that fall under specific protection, a subset of primary prevention. Which of the following interventions does NOT come under the primary level of prevention for specific protection? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Hand washing

 

  • Specific protection mode of disease prevention: Is a Primary level of disease prevention (applied when risk factors are present in environment but disease has not yet taken place).
  • Risk factors are already present but disease is prevented from occurring by using a specific modality. Ex - Vaccines & Vit A supplementation under NIS, chemoprophylaxis, IFA supplementation, contraception, ITN, etc
  • Handwashing fall within the category of primary prevention as a Health Promotion measure, not specific protection, as it is not a protective measures targeted at any particular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningitis prophylaxis in exposed contacts/relatives: This is a form of specific protection, aimed at preventing the onset of meningitis in those exposed to the infection.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccination is a classic example of specific protection, preventing the occurrence of specific diseases.

 

Option D. Adding iron to wheat flour: This is a specific protection measure to prevent iron deficiency anemia in the population by fortifying commonly consumed food products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hand washing is a health promotion measure and does not fall under specific protection in primary prevention strategies.
  • Note - Chinese Medicine is the Pioneer in concept of ‘Specific protection by vaccine’
