questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). According to the World Health Organization's guidelines, which of the following treatment schedules is recommended? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months

 

  • WHO defines Multi-drug resistant (MDR) Tuberculosis strain as Resistant to INH and Rifampicin with or without resistant to other anti TB drugs

 

Treatment of MDR-TB:

 

  • DOTS PLUS (Older name: Category IV)
  • Must be done on basis of sensitivity testing
  • Directly observed therapy certainly helps to improve outcomes and is considered an integral part of MDR-TB treatment
    • The recommended treatment regimen for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) involves a two-phase approach.
    • In the initial phase, patients are prescribed a combination of seven drugs for a duration of 4 to 6 months. These seven drugs are collectively referred to as CHOBZEE, which stands for Clofazimine, High dose Isoniazid, Levofloxacin, Bedaquiline, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Ethionamide.
    • Following the initial phase, the treatment enters a second phase where four drugs are continued for an additional 5 months. These four drugs are collectively known as COZE, consisting of Clofazimine, Levofloxacin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol. Note: Bedaquiline is always given for 6 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

New Regimens for Treatment Drug Resistant TB (RNTCP 2017-18)

 

 

(Drugs: Hh: High dose isoniazid; E:Ethambutol; Z:Pyrazinamide; K:Kanamycin; Cm: Capreomycin; A Amikacin; L: Levofloxacin; M: Moxifloxacin; Mh: High dose moxifloxacin; Et; Ethionamide; Cs: Cycloserine; Cz: Clofazimine; Lz: Linezolid; Bq: Bedaquiline

choices.text: Crude birth rate – Crude death rate
Crude birth rate + Crude death rate
Crude birth rate / Crude death rate
Crude birth rate × Crude death rate

questions.text: What is Demographic gap? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Crude birth rate – Crude death rate

 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate. It essentially measures the net increase in the population, referred to as the growth rate.

 

In demographic terms:

 

  • A positive demographic gap indicates that the birth rate is higher than the death rate, leading to population growth.
  • A negative demographic gap indicates a declining population when the death rate exceeds the birth rate.

 

The demographic gap is minimal during the early and late stages of the demographic transition model (Stages 1 and 4), where birth and death rates are balanced or declining. It peaks during Stage 2 when the birth rate remains high but the death rate drops significantly. In Stage 3, the gap starts to contract as birth rates begin to fall, and in Stage 5, it can become negative as populations age and birth rates fall below death rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The demographic gap is defined as the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate, representing the population growth rate

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducted a double-blind clinical trial comparing a new antidiabetic drug to a placebo. The study enrolled an equal number of participants in both arms. Based on the data below, what are the Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) and Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) for adverse effects? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RRR 11%, ARR 1%

 

Calculation -

 

  • Relative risk reduction (RRR): Percentage reduction in one outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR): Reduction in outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Event is taken as Occurrence of adverse outcome in the given example

 

In the given question,

 

Event rate Drug = 1603/15225 × 100 = 10.5% (0.105)

 

Event rate Placebo = 1804/15225 × 100 = 11.8% (0.118)

 

Hence,

 

  • Relative risk of Event rate = Event rate drug/Event rate Placebo = 0.105/0.118 = 0.9
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = (Event rate Placebo – Event rate drug)/Event rate placebo = (0.118)–0.105)/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%
  • Absolute risk reduction = Event rate Drug – Event rate Placebo = 0.105 – 0.118 = – 0.013 = – 1.3%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) reflects the proportionate reduction in risk between two groups, while the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) provides the difference in risk between them

questions.text: Vaccine kept at the lowest level inside an Ice lined refrigerator (ILR) at PHC: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) OPV

 

In an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR), which is commonly used at Primary Health Centers (PHCs) to store vaccines, the temperature varies from 2°C at the bottom to 8°C at the top. Vaccines that require colder temperatures, closer to 2°C, are stored at the lowest level of the refrigerator because cold air settles down.

 

OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine): OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR because it requires a colder environment. It can even tolerate freezing temperatures and can be stored in a deep freezer at -15°C to -25°C, making it suitable for the coldest section of the refrigerator.

 

  • Lyophilized vaccines like BCG, measles, and rotaviral vaccine are also stored at lower levels since they need a stable and colder temperature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCG: While BCG is a lyophilized vaccine and is stored at a lower level, it is not specifically the answer for this question as OPV is more specifically associated with the lowest level due to its freezing tolerance.

 

Option C. DPT: DPT vaccine is stored at the upper levels of the ILR where temperatures are closer to 6-8°C. This vaccine does not require the colder conditions found at the bottom of the refrigerator.

 

Option D. Rotaviral vaccine: Similar to BCG, the rotaviral vaccine is a lyophilized vaccine stored lower in the ILR, but OPV is the more critical vaccine stored at the lowest level due to its requirement for cold and even freezing conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions, ranging from 2°C and even tolerating freezing conditions, ensuring vaccine potency and effectiveness.

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Poisson distribution

 

Poisson Distribution

 

  • It is a ‘discrete probability distribution’ that expresses the ‘probability of a number of events occurring in a fixed period of time’ (if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event).
  • It can also be used for the number of events in other specified intervals such as distance, area or volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binomial distribution is used for those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poisson’s distribution.

 

Option B. Gaussian distribution and Option D. Normal distribution is the distribution of values of a quantitative variable such that they are symmetric with respect to a middle value with same mean, median and mode, and then the frequencies taper off rapidly and symmetrically on both sides – ‘bell shaped distribution’.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

questions.text: A healthcare professional is reviewing vaccine protocols to update patient information materials. In doing so, she focuses on the type of vaccine used for diphtheria prevention. Which option correctly describes the type of diphtheria vaccine? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Toxoid

 

  • The diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine, which involves the use of toxins produced by the bacterium that causes the disease.
  • These toxins are chemically inactivated to form toxoids, which are safe for use in vaccines but still capable of eliciting a strong immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of vaccine -

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the nutritional targets of Mid-Day Meal Program, as per the Indian government guidelines? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1/2 protein and 1/3 calorie requirements

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
    • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
    • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
    • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
    • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
    • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal -

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: In the infectious disease ward, you notice a multi-drug therapy packet placed neatly on a patient's bedside table. Based on the drug composition, which of the following diseases do you think the packet is intended to treat? [AIIMS NOV 2018]

The given image shows the adult blister packet used in the treatment of leprosy.

Option C. Vaginal discharge: Treatment for vaginal discharge depends on the specific cause, such as bacterial, fungal, or protozoal infection, and usually involves single-agent therapy.

questions.text: As a young pediatrician practicing in India, you attend various workshops and training sessions to keep yourself updated with the latest guidelines in child health. questions.text: A person reported to OPD alongside his 32-year-old brother working in a factory. The brother was recently subjected to a test – Coproporphyrin in urine. The physician should suspect: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lead poisoning

 

The presence of coproporphyrin in urine is commonly associated with lead exposure, making it an important screening test for lead poisoning. Coproporphyrin in urine indicates exposure to lead, but it does not confirm whether significant absorption has occurred. To determine absorption, a specific diagnostic test called Aminolevulinic Acid in Urine (ALAU) is used.

 

CPU – screening test – indicates lead Exposure - >150 mcg/L

 

ALAU – diagnostic test – indicated lead absorption - > 5mg/L

 

Elevated levels of lead in urine (>800 µg/L) signify both exposure and absorption, while levels above 700 µg/L indicate the onset of clinical symptoms.

 

Lead poisoning, also known as plumbism, is treated with chelation therapy using EDTA combined with dimercaprol, which helps remove lead from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, common in mining, quarrying, and glass manufacturing industries. It does not involve testing for coproporphyrin in urine.

 

Option B. Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as “brown lung disease,” is caused by inhaling cotton, flax, or hemp dust, mainly affecting textile workers. It is unrelated to coproporphyrin levels in urine.

 

Option C. Bagassosis: Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling dust from bagasse, the fibrous residue of sugarcane. This condition is not associated with lead exposure or coproporphyrin levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Coproporphyrin in urine is an important screening test for lead poisoning, indicating exposure to lead, and should be followed by diagnostic tests to assess absorption.

questions.text: A study on postpartum depression in mothers compares depression rates based on the gender of their newborns using the Edinburgh Depression Scale Score (EDSS). Which statistical method should be used to determine if there's a significant association between the newborn's gender and postpartum depression? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Chi square test

 

  • The Chi-square test serves the purpose of comparing qualitative data and involves the comparison of two groups with independent measurements.
  • Therefore, it is the most suitable test for this context

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Students t test: Used for comparing means of two independent groups; not suitable for categorical data.

 

Option B. Paired t test: Used for comparing means of related groups; not suitable for independent categorical data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means of three or more groups; not suitable for categorical data with only two groups.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Range

 

  • Range is expressed as minimum - maximum (or maximum – minimum) values in a given set of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: It is given as square of standard deviation (Deviation of each value from the standard value).

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation (COV): It is a measure used to compare relative variability.

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between Q1 and Q3 gives the interquartile range.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

questions.text: A 33-year-old public health officer is assigned to lead a healthcare team aiming to address and manage endemic conditions in a remote village with limited healthcare access. As part of the initiative, there's a proposal to start a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting common health concerns in the area. Which of the following conditions would NOT traditionally be managed through mass drug administration? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vitamin A deficiency 

 

  • Mass Drug Administration (MDA) refers to providing a drug to an entire population without considering age and gender.
  • Vitamin A prophylaxis is exclusively administered as per the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) to children up to the age of 5.
  • This prophylactic treatment is not intended as a curative measure but rather as a preventive measure.
  • Treatment with vitamin A is reserved solely for children displaying symptoms of vitamin A deficiency, and such treatment is not widespread throughout the community.
  • As a result, it is not categorized as part of Mass Drug Administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Worm infestation: Managed through MDA using albendazole or mebendazole to treat and prevent worm infestations in the population.

 

Option C. Scabies: Managed through MDA using ivermectin to treat and prevent scabies outbreaks in the community.

 

Option D. Filariasis: Managed through MDA using DEC (diethylcarbamazine) and albendazole to prevent and control filariasis in endemic areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency is managed through targeted prophylaxis in children rather than mass drug administration.
  • In contrast, MDA is carried out for conditions like scabies (using ivermectin), worm infestations (using albendazole), and filariasis (using DEC + albendazole).

choices.text: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.text: You're an intern in a bustling hospital laboratory. As you're overseeing the day's activities, you notice that a newly appointed technician accidentally spills a blood sample on the floor. The technician, looking panicked, turns to you for guidance. Given the potential risks associated with blood spills, what is the most immediate and appropriate action you should instruct the technician to take? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Clean with absorbable material

 

  • In this situation, the next crucial action to take is to utilize absorbent material for cleaning up the spilled blood. Once the cleaning is complete, the used absorbent material should be disposed of in the designated yellow bin. Subsequently, a sodium hypochlorite solution is employed to thoroughly decontaminate the affected surface. The specific concentrations of sodium hypochlorite employed are as follows:
    • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
    • >10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Call the infection control team of the hospital: While important, this is not the immediate action to take to contain the spill.

 

Option B. Mop it: Mopping without proper absorbent material and decontamination procedures could spread the contamination.

 

Option C. Cover it with 1% sodium hypochlorite: This step should follow the initial clean-up with absorbent material to ensure thorough decontamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypochlorites in Hospital waste Management

 

  • Disinfection of countertops and floors
  • Decontamination of blood spills
  • Irrigating agent in endodontic treatment
  • Disinfectant for manikins, laundry, dental appliances, hydrotherapy tanks
  • Treatment of liquid medical waste before disposal
  • Decontaminating water distribution systems in dialysis

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for dengue is being evaluated using a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) graph. As the curve transitions from the green region to the pink region, what is the most likely change in the test characteristics? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Both sensitivity and specificity increase

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, both sensitivity and specificity experience an increase.

 

  • Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)

 

Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

  • Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)

 

Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

 

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, it increases the count of true positives and negatives while decreases the occurrences of false positives and negatives. Consequently, this shift results in increased sensitivity and specificity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On an ROC graph, a transition from one region to another indicating improved test performance generally means that both sensitivity and specificity are increasing.

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted with dengue hemorrhagic fever. After several days of management, her condition stabilizes, and the medical team considers discharging her. Which of the following is an appropriate criterion to decide the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) After the return of appetite

 

  • The appropriate criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock include several clinical signs indicating recovery and stability.
  • One crucial criterion is the return of appetite, which signifies a significant clinical improvement and recovery from the acute phase of the illness.

 

SIGNS OF RECOVERY: 

 

  • Stable pulse, blood pressure and breathing rate
  • Normal temperature
  • No evidence of external or internal bleeding
  • Return of appetite
  • No vomiting
  • Good urine output 
  • Stable haematocrit 
  • Convalescent confluent petechiae rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol: The absence of fever should be without the use of antipyretics like paracetamol.

 

Option C. Urine output more than 200 ml: This is not a standard criterion; adequate urine output should be considered, but specific volume thresholds are not typically used.

 

Option D. After 24 hours from recovery of shock: Recovery from shock should be sustained, and other criteria like appetite and clinical stability are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRITERIA FOR DISCHARGING PATIENTS: 

 

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy
  • Return of appetite
  • Visible clinical improvement 
  • Good urine output 
  • Minimum of three days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion and no ascites
  • Platelet count of more than 50,000/mm

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A team of oncologists is implementing a new treatment strategy for metastatic melanoma that significantly improves overall survival rates for patients. How would you categorize the change in incidence and prevalence of metastatic melanoma in the population treated at this center? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a new treatment which can extend overall survival but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence increases and prevalence reduces: Incorrect as the new treatment does not affect the number of new cases.

 

Option B. Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same: Incorrect because the incidence is unaffected by treatment, and the prevalence would increase due to longer survival.

 

Option D. Incidence reduces and prevalence increases: Incorrect because the incidence remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Note - A treatment that extends the lives of patients with a chronic condition will increase prevalence, even if incidence remains stable.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to OPD with fever and neurological complications. He was having respiratory difficulty during the examination. Identify the disease transmitted through the life cycle shown in the image. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus disease


The life cycle shown in the image involves Pteropus bats, also known as fruit bats or flying foxes, which are natural reservoirs for the Nipah virus. The transmission cycle depicted shows bats contaminating fruits or other food sources with their secretions, which can then be consumed by humans or other animals like pigs, leading to the spread of the virus. Nipah virus is known for causing severe respiratory illness and neurological symptoms, with a high fatality rate of around 50%. There is no vaccine for Nipah virus, and treatment is primarily supportive and symptomatic.

 

Incubation period – 4-14 days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus disease: Zika virus is primarily transmitted through mosquito bites and does not involve bats or fruit contamination in its transmission cycle. It primarily causes mild symptoms and is not associated with the severe respiratory and neurological symptoms described here.

 

Option B. Dengue disease: Dengue is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and does not involve bats or fruit contamination. It typically presents with fever, headache, and joint pain rather than severe neurological symptoms or respiratory difficulty.

 

Option C. Yellow fever disease: Yellow fever is also transmitted through mosquito bites, mainly the Aedes and Haemagogus species, and does not involve bats. It causes fever, jaundice, and bleeding but does not match the transmission cycle or clinical presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:


Nipah virus is transmitted through contact with Pteropus bats, contaminated food, or animals that have been exposed to the virus. It causes severe respiratory and neurological symptoms with a high fatality rate and no available vaccine.

questions.text: Based on the emblem as shown below, which of the following best describes the warning it signifies? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Radiation hazard

 

INTERNATIONAL RADIATION SYMBOL (TREFOIL)

 

  • Central circle of radius R, an internal radius of 1.5R and an external radius of 5R for the blades, which are separated from each other by 60°
  • Trefoil is black in the international version
  • Commonly referred to as a Radioactivity warning sign, but it is actually a warning sign of ionizing radiation
  • Includes X-ray apparatus, medical beam cannons and particle accelerators.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytotoxic waste: This waste includes materials that are toxic to cells, such as chemotherapy waste, but uses a different symbol.

 

Option B. Biomedical waste: This refers to waste generated from medical procedures, often marked with a biohazard symbol.

 

Option D. Biohazard: Indicates the presence of biological substances that pose a threat to human health, marked with a different symbol.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A study on 100 urban women evaluates potential risk factors for breast cancer using odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). An OR > 1 with a CI not including 1 suggests a significant association. How many risk factors show a statistically significant association with breast cancer? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3

 

In the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant.

 

A high socioeconomic status does not pose a risk factor. Despite observing a positive correlation, the statistical significance is absent. Any correlation with a 95% confidence interval with the value of 1.0 is deemed as statistically insignificant. A value of 1.0 within this range implies that both factors can coexist without one being the cause of the other.

Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:

 

  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative (protective) association.

 

Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

There are three factors (early menarche, BRCA mutation, obesity), that have statistically significant associations with breast cancer according to the odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals provided.

choices.text: Normal distribution, evident outliers, negative skewness, positive skewness
Evident positive skewness, normal distribution, negative skewness, outliers present
Binominal distribution, outliers present, skewed negatively, skewed positively
Standard distribution, outliers present, evident positive skewness, negative skewness

questions.text: A hospital biostatistician analyzes patient wait times over several months to find patterns and outliers for optimizing patient flow. After analyzing four different months, the following box plots are created to illustrate the findings. Based on the given plots, match the correct description? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Normal distribution, evident outliers, negative skewness, positive skewness

 

  1. Plot 1 – Normal distribution
    • The box is roughly centered with whiskers of nearly equal length on both sides and no extreme values. This symmetry and lack of outliers indicate an approximately normal spread of wait times.
  2. Plot 2 – Evident outliers
    • Two data points lie clearly beyond the upper whisker (marked in red). These are outliers, while the central box and whiskers remain fairly symmetric.
  3. Plot 3 – Negative skewness
    • The lower whisker (toward shorter wait times) is substantially longer than the upper whisker, and the median line sits above the box’s center. This shows a left (negative) skew, where a few very short waits pull the lower tail.
  4. Plot 4 – Positive skewness
    • The upper whisker (toward longer wait times) is longer than the lower whisker, and the median is below the box’s center. This pattern reflects a right (positive) skew, due to some unusually long waits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and whisker plot 

 

  • Description: A convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles 
  • Edges of box: 1st and 3rd Quartile 
  • Line in Box: 2nd Quartile (Median) 
  • Whiskers end: Minimum & maximum values 
  • Outlier: A data point that is located outside the whiskers of the box plot
